result.title: Objective
result.description: The biodiversity of the Eastern Montane Forests is adequately represented and managed within KenyaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s PA network

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 65,000 ha of forests gazetted or reclassified to higher status and with improved governance systems and financial scoring allowing for effective management

baseline.comment: 145,000 ha of forests in Western Kenya focus landscapes under inadequate form of protected area status

target.comment: 65,000 ha of forests in Western Kenya under new or improved PA status; by EOP a marked increase by over in financial scorecards results: total with the 30,000 ha below is 95,000ha under improved management

actual.comment: Consolidated the governance and management of the PAs designated as core conservation areas, in respective Ecosystem Strategic Plans, in the three PA landscapes through; implementation of strategic plans, operation plans and development of another five Forest Station areas Participatory Forest Management Plans (PFMPs) for the stations that still had none. Joint Forest Level Management Committees as provided for in the subsidiary forest legislation and guidelines were instituted for 3 forest stations in the Nandi PA where the Kenya Forest Service (KFS) and Community Forest Associations (CFAs) have signed co-management agreements. The experience from Nandi is a model for CFAs in the other forest station areas that are yet to officially attain the management rights from KFS

target.comment: Threats reduction by 10%

actual.comment: Quarterly forest protection meetings held jointly, at all forest stations, between the Forest Manager and their Rangers (KFS), the CFAs Executive and Scouts, and the Ecosystem Conservators (KFS). The teams reviewed illegal forest resource utilization occurrence incidences/reports and the success of the enforcement regimens they employ, and effectiveness of the joint action plans implementation on forest protection and integrity/health of the forest stand. The Patrol Units provided with digital cameras and logistical support for documentation of incidences and quick response respectively. Recorded incidences down by 40%, even in view of the increased surveillance and intelligence collection from the forest adjacent community: patrol and surveillance efforts of units double or triple for respective forest areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improved systems level operations capacity has ensured a reduced level of threats to forest cover and species composition; Landscapes maintain global biodiversity values; METT scores are improved in target landscapes

baseline.comment: Forest management practices continue, leading to stable or ongoing loss to forest cover and species composition and coverage, measured by declining METT scores

target.comment: An increase in METT scores across the four landscapes by over 20% on average; monitoring indicates species diversity either unaffected or increased

actual.comment: Notable drop in METT in the two PAs: Kakamega down to 71 from 76; Cherengani down to 89 from 108; but an increase in Nandi 85 up from 82. This drop may be due to changes in the persons scoring: there have been transfer of key officers under the new KFS restructuring to conform to the devolved governance system in Kenya. Secondly, with capacity building that has led to better understanding of forest management and thus higher bench-marks for the management teams, some elements have scored lower than in previous years. Especially for the Cherengani Hills where there was very little if any engagement of stakeholders, the low levels of achievement were highly scored, but with exposure and knowledge of levels to aspire for the scores have lowered.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Systemic and Institutional Capacities for Managing an Expanded and Rationalized PA Estate

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: New PAs established: 20,000 ha; threatened forest reserves forests reclassified to higher management category: National Reserve (20,000 ha.)/Nature Reserve( 25,000 ha)

baseline.comment: PA status in Western Kenya remains under inadequate levels of protection throughout

target.comment: 65,000ha of threatened forests given higher protection status, of which 20,000 are newly protected areas and 45,000 ha under enhanced protected status

actual.comment: Change in classification still being explored in context of the proposed management regimens and the IUCN relevant categories. Current designations are in the context of the Kenya Constitution 2010 and the Kenya Forest Service management zonation based on allowable programs of conservation and utlisation.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Governance systems provide for the effective administration of the PA system as part of the regional development agenda by effective mainstreaming into local planning

baseline.comment: Forest management practices continue, with threats not contained, owing in large part to a lack of community level engagement in management

target.comment: 10 Community Conservation Areas established as new PAs 10 Joint Forest Management systems established in the buffer areas

actual.comment: All CCAs have active Management Committees and that jointly oversee the utilization of natural resources in the designated areas with the national or county responsible bodies with mandates to manage the sites. The oversight is guided by Annual Action Plans for the CCAs with most meeting twice on average within a quarter.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase in PA budget of 50 % over baseline of US$ 5 mill$ p.a. covers recurrent costs of forest protected area system (PA Financial Score

baseline.comment: Kenya's forests remain underfunded leading to habitat encroachment and reduction in species biodiversity

target.comment: Financial scorecard shows significantly improved results, with PAs receiving sufficient funds to be managed effectively

actual.comment: Fundraising undertaken but with no significant additional grants realized from other development partners within the year. The county governments engaged in extensive on-farm tree planting within the settlement areas of the landscape with over 1 million trees planted in the three PAs: forest extension functions (that is forestry activity outside of the gazetted forests) was devolved to the county governments. There was some increase in the development budgets of the national institutions to the local forest stations but the amount is yet to be fully quantified in the financial scorecards .

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Reduction in forest loss in unprotected forest blocks. CCAs established covering a target area of up to 10,000 ha.

baseline.comment: Connectivity between forest protected areas and unprotected forest blocks remains under threat or continues to be lost

target.comment: CCAs have established an additional area of up to 10,000 ha on formerly unprotected forest blocks

actual.comment:
CCAs management committees continue to engage with responsible bodies to implement Action Plans; and some of the county authorities have indicated/committed support to the management of the CCAs. Officials of the CCAs are included in the county planning forums/committees and hence planned Actions for the CCAs are mainstreamed into the respective county plans.
CFAs have become an integral part of the forest station conservation and management teams at the 16 stations in the PAs. The key roles of patrol, plantation establishment and awareness creation and education of the wider communities is a role they have fully taken up.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Reduction in forest degradation at the forest edge through the creation of JFM buffer zones in Forest PAs (target area up to 20,000 ha)

baseline.comment: Forest degradation and deforestation levels maintained at increased as buffer zones continue to be threatened by encroachment activity

target.comment: Up to 20,000ha of existing forest protected areas have been allocated to JFM

actual.comment: CFAs engage in alternative livelihood activities that are compatible with forest conservation; also undertake awareness and education amongst the wider community who are non-CFA members on the dangers their continued actions pose to livelihoods security; patrol and link with Kenya Forest Service/Kenya Wildlife Service and other agencies in enhancing enforcement. Buffer areas as delineated in the Participatory Forest Management (PFM) plans are being mainstreamed into development and land sue plans of the respective local governments where the PAs are located. Strategies such as those for grazing address the utilization of the buffer areas that fall within the gazetted forest areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Cost drivers for PAs are reduced as community acceptance of PAs leads to a reduction of PA incursions

baseline.comment: Forest management remains a costly process, with management resources unable to meet the challenges to forest integrity

target.comment: Cost of managing forest systems reduced as community support adds, rather than depletes, management resources

actual.comment: All 16 CFAs enhanced their participation in forest management and policing. Three CFAs that have signed Forest Management Agreements that confer full authority to co-mange with KFS and are lobbying for a more formalized engagement in routine decision making processes and benefit sharing from any revenues from forest produce utilization. An additional 62 community scouts trained and equipped in forest and CCA protection: they volunteer their services in the current set-up.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: PA management system effectively integrates conservation needs and local livelihoods.

baseline.comment: Forests remain under threat due a lack of alternative livelihood options

target.comment: Business plans define income generation opportunities from sustainable use of forests.

actual.comment: Additional declared incomes to forest adjacent community through forestry related enterprises was about USD 18, 717,000/=: seedlings sales from tree nurseries (USD 150,000/=); beekeeping (USD 28,800/=); PELIS (USD 35,300/=); ecotourism guiding services (USD 4,000/=); energy saving cook-stoves fabrication ans sales (USD .2,100/=) and wood biomass stocks on-farm woodlots. There has also been marked savings from the use of energy saving cook-stoves as the weekly households fuel wood requirements have been reduced by 60%. Thus those engaged in fuel wood collection have more time for other development activities.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Operational Capacities for PA Site Management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Protected Areas are managed to generate effective global and national and local environmental benefits, by agencies with functional capacity (measured by site level Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool).

baseline.comment: METT scores remain at status quo levels or decline as operational capacities for PA management do not increase at a sufficient rate

target.comment: An increase in METT scores across the four landscapes by over 20% on average;

actual.comment: A decrease in METT scores was noted for the year at two of the PAs:Kakamega down to 71 from 76; Cherengani down to 89 from 108; and increase in Nandi 85 up from 82. This drop may be due to changes in the persons scoring: there have been transfer of key officers under the new KFS restructuring to conform to the devolved governance system in Kenya. Secondly, with capacity building that has led to better understanding of forest management and thus higher bench-marks for the management teams, some elements have scored lower than in previous years. Especially for the Cherengani Hills where there was very little if any engagement of stakeholders, the low levels of achievement were highly scored, but with exposure and knowledge of levels to aspire for the scores have lowered.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Reduction in forest loss and degradation in forest blocks covering an area of 175,000 ha in western Kenya.

baseline.comment: Deforestation and forest degradation remains static or increases in forest PA estate of Western Kenya

target.comment: monitoring indicates species diversity either unaffected or increased

actual.comment: Overall there was Increased forest cover in re-habilitated, re-afforetsed and where forest dwellers were evicted.Additional areas (back-log plantation areas) replanted under the Plantation Establishment and Livelihood Improvement Scheme of the Kenya Forest Service with the leadership of the Community Forest Associations at the respective forest stations.Populations of key taxa monitored was stable:annual monitoring by community biodiversity monitors and National Museums of Kenya were conducted once (basic monitoring and common bird monitoring) and twice (detailed dry and wet season monitoring) for specific sites.

location.name: Garissa

result.title: Objective
result.description: To provide land users and managers with the enabling policy, institutional and capacity environment for effective adoption of SLM in the agropastoral production system.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Improvement in rangeland condition

baseline.comment: Various statistics report that about 80% of rangelands badly degraded

target.comment: At least 25% of the rangeland registering improvement in rangeland condition in pilot districts (using range condition measurements) by mid-term and 50% cumulative by end of the project

actual.comment: This indicator is still on target. All the four pilot project areas (Mbeere North, Kyuso, Narok North and Dadaab) have continued implementing measures aimed at rehabilitating communal degraded lands as well as on-farm soil and water conservation interventions. This is largely through physical and biological conservation measures instituted at both landscape and farm level and impressive recovery results are evident with about 45% recovery of baseline situation. The initiative through KEFRI enabled identification of suitable tree species for the dryland ecosystems and communities have embraced planting them. These include species Neem (Azidirachta Indica) which is doing wonderfully well in Dadaab and has been embraced by schools and individuals due to its multi-purpose nature. In the field of enabling environment and institutional capacity building, the project has partnered with KAPSLM in facilitating CSOs form County platforms which in turn will act as vehicles for the County SLM Strategic Investment Framework (CSIF) through which lobbying and advocacy for SLM funding could be actualized.The County governments have been looped in for sustainability of this initiative.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improvement in woodlands condition

baseline.comment: Various statistics report that about 70% of the woodlands are degraded

target.comment: At least 25% of woodlands showing recovery as measured by regeneration and improvements in species index and canopy cover;

actual.comment: Woodland conditions and wood cover improvements are evident in the pilot areas. Several suitable tree species identified by KEFRI have been planted by communities and significant survival rates recorded. During the reporting period, the project implemented various land rehabilitation activities including re-seeding of 2172 hectares of degraded lands with pastures in the four pilot districts. The Project also distributed 99,778 tree seedlings and 14,995 fruit trees to communities in Narok, Kyuso, Dadaab and Mbeere North districts with an aim of increasing tree cover. The percentage tree cover in the long run will significantly increase since farmers are well sensitized and trained on agro-forestry tree management, afforestation and efforts to increase tree planting are supported by FFS group nurseries.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Quantity of land managed using SLM principles

baseline.comment: Limited land under SLM, no clear documentation on what little is under SLM

target.comment: At least 70,000 ha total (28 sites*2500 ha ) under SLM principles supported by experiential learning

actual.comment: The project is active in an area covering 640,000 Ha, over which it is making significant contributions towards adoption of SLM practices. The Farmer Field Schools (FFS) are the entry points for SLM technologies. A total of 54 FFS with total membership of over 1600 households are practicing landscape rehabilitation efforts and on-farm SLM practices. SLM principles in use include addressing the drivers of land degradation; reducing land degradation through keeping fewer but highly productive livestock breeds, planting trees and drought resistant crop seed varieties, practicing climate smart agriculture which involves use of weather information forecasts, water harvesting technologies, conservation agriculture, investing in soil fertility improvement, measures that reduce heavy use of bio-fuels e.g. improved charcoal kilns and use of energy efficient cook-stoves and other ecosystem restoration initiatives.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Improvement in food security

baseline.comment: Various statistics indicate that over 65% of people in ASAL depend in part on food aid and face substantive food insecurity

target.comment:
Level of dependency on food aid in target landscapes reduced by at least 30%;
Number of food secure days increased by at least 40% for more than 50% of the population in the target landscapes

actual.comment:
In the reporting period, the project has supported improvement of local livestock breeds for purposes of increasing productivity and resilience against diseases. In Narok, upgrading of livestock was undertaken, where 30 dorper breeding rams, 10 galla goats, and 60 kenbro cockerels and 100 langstroth and Kenya Top Bar hives were bought and distributed to farmer field schools and community members to boost upgrading of local breeds. In Kyuso, 528 Galla breeding goats, 610 poultry birds and 115 langstroth bee hives were bought and distributed to the community. In Mbeere North, 66 galla goats 52 dairy goats and 300, 1 month old rainbow rooster chicks and 100 langstroth bee hives were distributed to communities. In Dadaab, 32 dairy goats, 80 kurchi birds and 20 langstroth bee hives were bought and distributed to farmer field schools.
To enhance agricultural productivity in the pilot districts, the project also provided various drought resistant crops to FFS and the local communities. In Dadaab, a total of 720 kg of cow peas K20/KUU27, 1840 kg of green-grams N26, 1840kg maize DHO2 and 30kg of watermelon seeds were distributed to FFS. Mbeere North district distributed to the community and FFS a total of 752Kg of cowpeas M66, 308kg of maize KCB, 645kg of green-grams N26, 520 kgs of Sorghum Gardam, 192kgs of finger millet, 380kgs of beans, 158kgs of Dolichos. In Kyuso, the project bought and distributed 300 Kgs Dolichos, 300 Kgs Cow peas K80 200 kgs KVU27-1, 440kgs Pearl Millet, 490Kgs 1230 Kgs Green grams N26 and 880 Kgs Gadam Sorghum to FFS farmers to plant. In Narok North, 87 farmers from 2 Farmer Field Schools namely; Ilaretok, Orkilenyae FFS were trained on drought tolerant/resistant crops and best agro-pastoral practices while 45 farmers from Salbet and Omomet FFS were trained on water harvesting, fruit tree establishment. The two FFS were also trained on mulching and manure. The project also linked farmer field schools in Mulot with African Agricultural Technology Foundation who trained 62 farmers on drought Tego Maize which is a type of maize resistant to drought.
Food security enhancement has been realized as reported through statistics of community members who have been removed from relief food dependency/registers due to attaining self sufficiency in household food needs and increased incomes. A combination of supporting interventions have led to this favorable situation: continuous capacity building of FFS members on good agricultural practices, adoption of climate smart agriculture by the concerned communities, support in improved livestock breeds which have on average increased milk output.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Carbon mitigated from sustainable charcoaling

baseline.comment: Currently no sustainable charcoaling no carbon mitigated from it

target.comment: At least half a million tons of carbon dioxide mitigated from sustainable charcoal in the districts by mid-term and a million cumulative at the end of the project

actual.comment: The project has continued to supported adoption of energy efficient technologies in the pilot districts. In Narok, FFS members in Ewaso Ngiro, Suswa and Mulot over 300 farmers were trained on the use of the maendeleo jiko cooking stoves. A total 350 jikos were given to the trainees as a part of promoting energy efficient technologies in the district. The adoption and use of the jikos will reduce deforestation since less fuel wood is required. In Mbeere North, 200 rocket stoves were procured for the new FFS and one institutional jiko constructed at St. Michael Gacuriri Primary school and a charcoal kiln constructed at Kune. In Dadaab, 400 energy efficient cooking stoves were bought and distributed to FFS and community members. In Kyuso, a total of 105 maendeleo jikos cooking stoves were distributed to Muunda Mweu, Faith Youth and Makkki FFS. The project also supported establishment of three (3) charcoal kilns at Mitamisyi, Ngomeni and Kamusiliu. The established kilns have better carbonization control and hence higher yield of better quality charcoal.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Knowledge based land use planning forms the basis for improving drylands sustainable economic development

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage of land and resource users adopting improved practices

baseline.comment: Less than 20% engaging in 1-2 improved practices consistently

target.comment: At least 25% of cultivators in the pilot landscapes adopting 3-5 forms of improved practices by mid-term and 75% cumulatively by project end

actual.comment: This target continues to be exceeded as new FFS' are recruited and members trained on various SLM practices. Adoption rates are high since training is through demonstrations based on Agro-Ecological Systems Analysis (AESA) at the FFS demo plot with individual farmers replicating the learnt practice(s) on their farms. The range of improved farming practices include land preparations including suitable/appropriate WH technologies for crop production,erection of appropriate soil and water conservation measures, fertility improvement initiatives, choice of crop seed, timely planting based on weather forecasts, timely weeding and harvesting, managing post harvest losses, breed selection and improvement, observance of optimal stocking rates etc

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Change in soil fertility

baseline.comment: Very low and declining, exact levels for pilot districts obtained during inception

target.comment: At least 30% increase in soil fertility from baselines for land users consistently engaging in 3-5 improved practices by mid-term and by 30% cumulatively by end of the project

actual.comment: Results of soil fertility tests done by KARI were released to the individual farmers, each with a recommendation for soil fertility management unique to their own farm. Technical staff in the field have been instrumental in deciphering the recommendations to the farmers and guiding them (farmers) so that they get optimal crop production from their farms.Use of farmyard manure and /or commercial fertilizers and growing of nitrogen fixing crop varieties in rotation with other crops are some of the practices farmers are using. Use of animal/farmyard manure has been recommended for majority of the farmers on account of improving the water holding capacity of the soils and also aiding in improvement of soil structure.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Use of weather data for adapting SLM practices

baseline.comment: Less than 5% use of weather information provided by the early warning systems of Kenya Met and Dept of resource mapping and planning

target.comment: At least 25% of the agriculturalists and pastoralists in the pilot landscapes taking decisions on the basis of the weather and drought early warning information by mid-term and 50% cumulatively by project end

actual.comment: The use of weather information for farm decision making has been adopted by more than 60% of FFS community members. The uptake of the scientific/modern weather information has been commendable, save for the times when forecast falls short of prediction leading to loss of faith by users. District Management Team (DMT) members have been instrumental in relaying this information in conjunction with Kenya Meteorological Department staff working in the pilot Counties and through other stakeholders such as FBOs. Community based drought early warning information is disseminated to the pilot communities by National Drought Management Authority, again in conjunction with DMT.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of people with relevant skills for SLM

baseline.comment: Less than 15% of land users and pastoralists have skills for improved management; less than 50% of technical officers have updated SLM skills

target.comment: At least 40% of land users and 30% of technical officers requiring to up-date skills have done so by mid-term: by the end of project, at least 60% of land users and 75% of technical officers cumulatively have updated skills.

actual.comment: The target for technical staff training in SLM issues is overwhelmingly high (100%) since all staff operating in the pilot districts have had trainings pertaining to SLM. These include refresher trainings on soil conservation, environmental impact assessment and audit as well as agricultural products value addition. The project has also supported exchange tours for farmers in the pilot districts. In Mbeere, farmers visited Kieni East, Njoro, Nakuru, Kirinyaga and Laikipia. The visit enhanced their knowledge on water harvesting for crop and fodder production, dairy farming in dry areas, pasture production, small scale irrigation, beekeeping and melia production. In Narok, FFS members in Mulot and Ewaso Ngiro visited 6 farms belonging to fellow group members. In Dadaab, 15 PFS members and 6 DMT officer visited Chepareria, West pokot. The participant gained knowledge on pasture management, dry land farming and beekeeping. The skills and knowledge so acquired has cascaded down to the communities through FFS facilitators. Over 1600 community household members ( approx.12,000 persons) have benefited from agro ecological systems analysis trainings demonstrated at the FFS. Many other community members have been reached through field days, exhibitions, print and electronic media with an overall 50% of estimated target achieved. In addition, the project has also supported capacity building of the technical officers from the pilot districts as follows: 1 PhD 6 Master degrees, 4 diploma and 15 certificates courses.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Lessons generated

baseline.comment: Limited knowledge management happening now, no clear mechanism for generating and sharing lessons

target.comment: Lessons on improving land and resource tenure, range rehabilitation, sustainable charcoaling, improving livestock mobility, and other important project initiatives available for dissemination through the upscaling project;

actual.comment: Lessons generated and knowledge management continues to receive keen attention by all players. The M&E strategy employs a multi-layered system for generation of knowledge, dissemination and feedback loops. At community level critical and important SLM knowledge is generated and documented at the FFS level, jointly by FFS members and their facilitators through AESA. Lessons on improving land and resource tenure, range rehabilitation, sustainable charcoaling, crop and livestock improvement a.s.o are generated. These lessons are shared among group members and DMT who act as custodians of the same before onward transmission to PMU. PMU synthesizes this for UNDP and project board consumption, including making news bulletins. Other forms of knowledge is covered through field missions by PMU/PSC as they engage with the project beneficiaries. This is usually captured in back to office reports, file notes or technical reports. Research bodies and other stakeholders have also been generating knowledge through field trials and demos with FFS groups. Such information has been shared at stakeholder workshops and disseminated in form of SLM book. The UNDP and SLM websites continue to be credible avenues of disseminating knowledge learnt. Regional exchange visit in Arusha, Tanzania, CSOs workshop in Nakuru and Workshop for the Regional Pastoral Livelihoods Resilience Project are other avenues where sharing of experiences and lessons learnt has taken place. The project office has shared the lessons with the parent TerrAfrica /SIP Program through a monkey survey conducted on its behalf by a consulting firm.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Viability of the agropastoralism production system increased through diversification increased access to finance for SLM

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Change in agricultural productivity

baseline.comment: Current low and declining, exact levels of selected crops to be obtained during inception

target.comment: At least 20% increase in agricultural produce for key crops for those adopting 3-5 improved practices consistently by mid-term and 50% cumulative by project end

actual.comment: The increase in productivity is is evident in pilot area locations, with significant yields being reported even in times of drought. This stems from adoption of good agricultural practices by FFS farming communities. The true margin of improvements in farm yield would need a survey. Diversification into other livelihoods such as fish farming has taken place. Groups have been supported to start income generating activities such as bee keeping and weaving of mats and baskets. Access to finances has been achieved through involvement of relevant stakeholders such as banks and micro credit institutions. Equity bank has been involved in providing financial literacy to some of the SLM FFS groups, and extending credit facilities to willing farmers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in livestock trade and prices

baseline.comment: Currently livestock trading riddled with problems of insecurity, lack of up to date information on prices and therefore very low prices being obtained

target.comment: At least a 20% increase in livestock prices being obtained in markets within the pilot landscapes due to better marketing/trading conditions

actual.comment: The project has supported the development of livestock marketing yards and slaughter houses in a bid to improve livestock trade. Organized market trading has improved access to markets and livestock numbers and prices increased as brokers are kept at bay. Flayers have been trained on processing of hides and skins including marketing and are now fetching better money. However, insecurity in such areas as Dadaab is eroding the gains made by improving the trading infrastructure.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of households or individuals accessing micro finance and credits

baseline.comment: Less than 10% of households have access

target.comment: At least 25% increase in numbers accessing micro-finance and credits

actual.comment: The project has continued enhancing community linkages with various micro-finance institutions as previously reported. Access to credit is within easy reach for farmers but actual acquisition remains low on account of high cost of borrowing, most farmers are credit averse, banks hesitant to give credit for agricultural ventures in asals on account of high risk of incurring bad debts (high default rates) owing to frequent crop and livestock failures occasioned by droughts and climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increase in household income

baseline.comment: Over 85% of people live below the UN poverty line, living on less than a dollar a day; exact household incomes in the pilot landscape will be established during inception

target.comment: By mid project - at least 25% increase in household incomes for more than 40% of participating households, cumulatively rising to at least 40% for more than 50% of households

actual.comment: Diversification of farm enterprises continued taking centre stage in improving household incomes. Additional households income from fish farming has been introduced in Narok. This is aimed at improving both nutrition and incomes for the FFS group members and their families. The income generation activities previously reported were given more attention during the period under review i.e. more drought tolerant crop seeds planted, more bee-hives distributed and apiaries established, mores dairy goats and improved chicken reared. Generally incomes at household level for FFS beneficiaries have increased by approximately 30% from baseline situation.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Mobile livestock

baseline.comment: The current trend is tilted to fast rates of sedenterization; specific baseline will be obtained during inception

target.comment: At least 50% of current mobile pastoralists still retain livestock mobility by the end of the project

actual.comment: The project continued to support livestock mobility through peace building meetings along livestock corridors, disease surveillance and vaccinations in the pilot district. In Mbeere North, spot vaccination was conducted for goats against Contagious Caprine Pleuropneumonia and surveillance of diseases along Ishiria- Mwingi and Tharaka stock routes.The project has also improved infrastructure in the pilot districts such as livestock sale yards and loading ramps, watering points, disease control programmes including vet lab services along the routes and dry season grazing areas) in cross-border planning. This, together with the on-going support to pastoral communities in the pilot sites has hopefully brought a fair percentage of the livestock keepers on productive and sustainable mobility mode.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Incidents of conflicts over resources (inter and intra pastoralists and agriculturalists)

baseline.comment: Very high number of incidents of conflicts, specific baseline will be obtained during inception

target.comment: At least 10% reduction in incidents of conflicts over land and resources in the pilot districts and a cumulative 50% reduction by project end

actual.comment: The support given to pastoralists in growing/ establishing pastures at landscape and individual farms has ensured a fair supply of the same during periods of scarcity. This has tremendously reduced pasture related conflicts in the pilot districts.Provision of requisite infrastructure such as water (pans and boreholes) and training of overseer committees has also ensured communities live in harmony with neighboring communities.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: The policy, regulatory and institutional environment support sustainable land management in the agropastoral production system and ASALs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of policies mainstreaming SLM

baseline.comment: All policy statements mention importance of SLM but don't have details of how SLM will be ensured

target.comment: At least 2 policies revised to mainstream SLM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SLM;

actual.comment: The support to SLM National platform has been on course. The devolved system of governance has necessitated a paradigm shift as most planning and funding of SLM interventions will be at County level. SLM in partnership with KAPSLM has rolled out support to establishment of County Strategic Investment Forum (CISF). This forum will lobby for mainstreaming of SLM interventions at the County level by deliberately planning for such interventions in the CIDPs, including budgetary support. SLM project has continued participating and facilitating the development of relevant policies such as Camel policy. The Project has also supported strengthening of traditional institutions to curb over-exploitation of natural resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of policies with legislation and institutional arrangement for effective implementation

baseline.comment: Few SLM policies have updated and effective frameworks well linked into the local institutions

target.comment: Discussions for legislation and institutional arrangement for policy implementation for at least 2 key policies held by mid-term and recommendations provided adopted by end of the project

actual.comment: There has been sustained focus on use of stakeholder organizations to bring this target to fruition. camel policy has been supported and is almost successful. CSOs and CECs have been well sensitized and will serve as the vehicles to spearhead SLM policy formulation at County level. Already the Central and South Rift Counties of Nakuru, Narok, Kericho, Kajiado, Buret and Baringo have elected officials to coordinate the lobbying and advocacy of SLM issues at County level.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of functional charcoal associations

baseline.comment: No charcoal associations

target.comment: At least 5 charcoal associations have rules and regulations for sustainable charcoal and are actively enforcing them;

actual.comment: The number of functional charcoal associations remains 5 (4 in Mbeere North and 1 in Kyuso). Narok has a few 'broker' registered associations, which have not been legally functional. The associations, though trained on new charcoal rules have faced teething problems because charcoal business has not been clearly understood/streamlined in terms of issuance of permits for production and transportation. Existence of brokers has only served to complicate the situation because they (brokers) produce charcoal in questionable environments.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of groups with operational sustainable charcoal processes

baseline.comment: No groups engaging in sustainable charcoal

target.comment: At least 5 groups with sustainable charcoal production operations and earning money from carbon finance;

actual.comment: The number of groups with operational sustainable charcoal processes has grown by 80% to 9 from 5 reported previously, (Mbeere 6 groups and Kyuso 3 groups). Efficient charcoaling kilns are gaining acceptance among the pilot communities and are likely to be the technology of choice moving forward. This is partly because they use branches instead of whole trees and also because of short time needed for a through-put (approx. 24 hours).

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Revenue from charcoal going to District and national revenue

baseline.comment: Minimal collection through licensing but none through taxation

target.comment: Collection of revenue by Districts and Kenya Revenue Authority from charcoal processes increase by 25% by mid-term and 50% cumulatively be end of the project;

actual.comment: Capturing of revenue streams from the County governments and KRA still remains a challenge, owing to unclear trading terms explained earlier in this report.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Adoption of improved kilns in carbonization

baseline.comment: Less than 5% use improved kilns in carbonization

target.comment: Number of charcoal producers using improved kiln in carbonization in pilot landscapes increase by at least 30% by mid-term and a cumulative 50% by project end

actual.comment: The baseline target has been surpassed by far.There are now 9 improved kilns in the project pilot areas compared to 5 reported previously representing an increase of 80% during the reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Improvement in local resource governance institutions

baseline.comment: Currently traditional institutions sidelined in natural resource management but formal institutions not effective at local level

target.comment: By mid project, traditional resource institutions in pilot landscapes have assessed the effectiveness of their rules and regulations in modern day resource governance and have identified ways to improve; be end of project several agreements entered into with formal institutions for resource governance

actual.comment: The traditional institutions for NRM have continued to play their roles as trained. Reduced conflicts over resources have been witnessed, courtesy of their timely interventions.
